string-array.name: brainstorming
string-array.item: Leaving Kickoff, the first thing your team should begin doing is brainstorming. No idea is a bad idea here, and this is the time to come up with all kinds of crazy designs. During this time you should begin planning strategy and deciding how and what you want your robot to do.

string-array.name: approaching_the_game
string-array.item: Before thinking about how your robot could accomplish the game, it is important for you to decide what you want to accomplish! You\'ll need a game-plan before you can design a robot. In order to design a robot around the best strategy, KING TeC stages a mock game using human players instead of robots immediately after Kickoff, revealing any strategies that may otherwise be overlooked.

string-array.name: game_rules
string-array.item: Fully understanding the rules of the new game is critical to the design process. Everyone on the team should read the rules at least once and your team should appoint a Rules Master, someone who your team can defer to for all rules-related questions.

string-array.name: getting_materials
string-array.item: While the details of your design may not be set in stone, it is important for your team to begin purchasing materials, especially materials that need to be shipped. Unfortunately you can\'t build a robot without supplies, and it is much better to be waiting for them during Weeks One and Two than during Week Six.\n\nHave your team put together a list of expected materials, and don\'t forget to include extras for any parts you think might break. Your priority should be getting the parts you need to start building!

string-array.name: prototyping
string-array.item: The teams on Einstein Field at the FRC World Championship consistently do one thing right. They test and test repeatedly, designing and breaking components of their robot before even thinking about assembling them into a finalized design. Prototyping allows teams to find flaws in their designs and fix them before it cuts into the crucial later weeks, where time and resources need to be spent on programming and drive practice. \n\nKING TeC assembles smaller two/three man teams that work on individual components of the robot. How you prototype is up to your team, but it is important to keep the process moving. Don\'t let a failure in one part constitute a failure as a whole!

string-array.name: chassis_building
string-array.item: Although you may not have a completely finalized robot design at this point in time, it is extremely important that you begin building the chassis. The drive-train is the heart of almost every robot design out there, and it is important to get a driving robot as soon as possible. Not only will having driving robot guarantee you some level of success on the field, without a frame the components and modules you are prototyping will have nowhere to go!

string-array.name: drive_practice
string-array.item: When competing at competition, nothing can make or break your teams experience than how your drivers work together and with the robot. While six weeks is not a lot of time to build a robot, it is important to find time to let your drivers practice. The earlier the better, but the season goes fast and we often are only able to practice driving during the last few days of the build season.

string-array.name: tweaking_programming
string-array.item: While you hopefully have the main functionality of your robot programmed by this point, odds are you won\'t get everything perfect the first time. Your programmers should be focusing on fixing the major bugs and getting everything working, but after that it is time to bring in the drive team.\n\nAlthough programmers like to think they know everything about the robot, it is important to remind them that they most likely won\'t be driving it at competition. If they will be, your team has lucked out! If not, the programmers should sit down with the drive team and fine tune the controls until the drivers are content.

string-array.name: late_build_changes
string-array.item: Like the real world, build season is often full of unexpected surprises. In the case of a robot-building emergency, don\'t panic. Last minute changes happen on every team, and the important thing to remember is that you can continue building after the six weeks are over.\n\n You are allowed to bring a small amount of robot-related parts to competition, which means you can manufacture parts at home and install them on the first day of competition.

string-array.name: bag_and_tag
string-array.item: While in the past your robot had to be crated up, in recent years a new procedure for sealing away your robot has been unveiled. All official events with the exception of the Championship are "Bag and Tag" events, meaning that your robot must be suffocated by a giant bag on the last day of Build Season. More information is available in the administrative manual.
